$$._: Wireless power transfer (WPT) is pivotal for powering electrical devices when cable connection is inconvenient or risky. Recent advancements in WPT technology stem from innovative physical mechanisms. This review examines these groundbreaking WPT mechanisms, the impact of 2D materials such as MXenes, graphene, and transition metal dichalcogenide monolayers on wearable and implanted bioelectronics. Essential aspects such as power transfer efficiency, material portfolio, 2D materials' significance, transferable power range, and primary influence areas are discussed. The review concludes with future WPT possibilities for wearable and implantable technologies, including novel antennas, transparent devices, bioresorbable implants, electrotherapy, haptic interface, ultrafast 2D diodes, transistors, charge pumps in the 5G/6G range, and wireless brain-machine interfaces.

Wireless power transfer (WPT) is key in areas where wired connections are not feasible, such as implanted bioelectronics. It opens new research possibilities across various fields including biomedical science, chemistry, and electrical engineering. WPT, powered by Two-dimensional (2D) materials, facilitates advancements in bioelectronics, wearable technology, soft robotics, and more. This review provides novel insights into 2D materials for WPT systems such as MXenes, graphene, and transition metal dichalcogenide monolayers. It deep dives into potential applications such as robust WPT, miniaturized devices, wearable tech, bioresorbable implants, electrotherapy, haptic interfaces, ultra-fast 2D diodes, transistors, and wireless-powered brain-machine interfaces for the 5G/6G range. Relevant to multidisciplinary research in electrical, biological, material, energy, and microelectronic engineering, it may shape future healthcare strategies involving WPT and brain-machine interfaces.

In an increasingly wireless world, powering devices where cables cannot reach is crucial. This paper explores how wireless power transfer (WPT) makes this possible, focusing on the significant role of two-dimensional materials such as MXenes, graphene, and metal dichalcogenides. Breaking new ground in wearable and implantable bioelectronics, these advances could revolutionize everything from health tech to communication. Looking to the future, the paper also discusses potential uses for these technologies, opening doors to exciting developments such as wireless brain-machine interfaces.
